message: I'm late to the 'bookmarking site' game and I just figured out delicious would work great for me, but last year's news (http://blog.delicious.com/blog/2010/12/whats-next-for-delicious.html) stop me from signing up. What service do you use?
Does any of these save the bookmarked page so I can read it after the server is taken down years later?
Diigo seems great -- this convore seems a little sketchy though.
Diigo is great
XMarks ... I HIGHLY recommend it to anybody :)
i had started only using it to save things to read later, which Instapaper is much better at anyway
i use pinboard for the rest
i think most of the modern ones do but it's usually a paid service (since that can be expensive)
I worked on Delicious after the Yahoo purchase and I moved over to pinboard.
thanks @markpasc

Diigo seems to cost $5/month for the advanced features... but I couldn't find this info on their main page (?), only on the community forums http://groups.diigo.com/group/Diigo_HQ/content/the-price-to-go-premium-1878377
http://pinboard.in/faq/#archiving
xmarks is $12/year for premium (the free version saves bookmarks for 3 months only?), but doesn't have archiving/indexing
ah, and archiving is “cached pages” http://help.diigo.com/premium-features/Cached-page
hmm, Diigo has some interesting research-oriented features like groups and in-page sticky notes
From pinboard's roadmap: "Get acquired by Yahoo and slowly grow useless" :)
+1 for pinboard.in.
Switched from Delicious to Pinboard.in. Great service
+1 for Diigo
I use Chrome all the time, so I use Chrome Sync which is built into the browser.  Else I would use Evernote or Instapaper.

Have used Delicious for years, but with the rumors of it being on shaky ground I have been sampling others.  Springpad has good potential, but does not yet have export capabilities ("soon", they say).  Netvouz is very much like Delicious and has become my home page and bookmarking tool, but seems to be a small team (one person?) running it.
google bookmarks and it's integration with Chrome is great!

Found some more suggestions in this stackexchange thread: http://webapps.stackexchange.com/questions/8641/where-can-i-store-my-private-bookmarks-online and on this wiki: http://autonomo.us/wiki/Delicious_replacements
@markpasc I've been doing the same thing: Instapaper for read it later and Pinboard for future reference
pinboard.in - love that they essentially modeled their API after the Delicious one, so most extensions were easily to switch over to pinboard for browser bookmarking.
I'm liking Pinboard as well. Automatically extracting links from Twitter favorites is a real plus for me.
Another vote for Pinboard. However the chrome extension (I'm actually on chromium) doesn't sync, always throws an error.
damn everyone loves pinboard, I feel oldschool on delicious

I use Scuttle - a self-hosted Delicious clone - for broad bookmarking. Essentially anything that I *might* want to refind even a year later goes in there. I hate remembering something I read in an article once and then not being able to find it.
+1 for Diigo. I like using the highlighting feature.
Pinboard!
thx @ericmoritz :)
+1 also for trunk.ly

I really like http://trunk.ly.  Instead of making me adopt the new behavior of bookmarking a page, I just have to share it on twitter, which I usually do anyway.  It's a service I've been meaning to write for two years.
I've become quite hooked on Springpad lately. It imported all my Delicious bookmarks and lets me annotations and such. I can also push links directly to my mobile phone from the browser bookmarklet.
+1 Pinboard and I love the Chrome extension.  I haven't had any issues with it.
mmm
*the star
i just click he *
its easy
It's just that sometimes you don't want everything bookmarked in your browser.
the one built into chrome
Some things are worth making note of for future reference, but not worth putting in your bookmarks/favorites.

with the delicious fiasco I looked hard and Diigo was a real winner the chrome add-ins with sync  and Android apps rock and as a clever bonus they auto save the links you favorite on Twitter, That made me fall in love, and I think I've just scratched the surface..
Trunkly sounds good if you post links to twitter, i always like removing steps. i don't generally do that, so i love that Pinboard can subscribe to what i star in Instapaper.
same reason i wouldn't really use http://laterstars.com/ , twitter favorites already mean something else to me
I'm using a local installation of http://www.frech.ch/online-bookmarks
nevertheless, I'd like to use something local which I could use to sync it with chrome. For instance, I thought about installing xmarks for using it with WebDAV, but this feature is firefox-only.
i wondered why nobody uses Hatena Bookmark, since i forgot it's not in english. they only localize Flipnote, Star and Haiku, i guess: http://www.hatena.com/
@ryanthejenks I agree. Also, if you're the kind of person who uses a lot of different computers (like me) then bookmarks in the browser are almost worthless if they don't sync to other systems.
I use the Chrome one too, as it's really convenient. Then I have all my bookmarks anywhere I go (sync'd to my google account).

Just because Yahoo is done with Delicious doesn't mean it's going to be scuttled. Aren't they already talking to buyers? I'm confident it'll be around for a long time to come. I have so much workflow bound up in Delicious (four machines with three browsers each, all with Delicious plugins installed, everyone on our staff using it...) that I'm in no rush to ditch the service.

@markpasc TETO,  I already habituated the behavior of sending links to twitter so trunk.ly was an easy migration; I can see how if someone how doesn't do that wouldn't like trunk.ly.  The only fault of trunk.ly is, at last I checked, I can't have private bookmarks.

http://www.xmarks.com/ is awesome multi-browser/computer bookmark syncing. For life more offline you can't go wrong with Evernote.com - it's not bookmarking per se, but when you clip from the web you'll get a permalink. Highly recommend both.

@shacker There was some discussion from insider folks when the delicious news broke that the service is tied to a lot of internal Yahoo! tech by now, so a buyer would need to re-architect that, or Yahoo! license more than just the delicious tech. Pinboard is delicious API compatible, so plugins can update easily (but still need to update for the API end point at least).
@thankUverymuch xmarks will be discontinued (or probably continued as a paid service). If I'd be an user of this site, I searched for alternatives ... http://blog.xmarks.com/?p=1886
Historious, for its great search, chrome extension, simplicity: http://historio.us/referrals/MTc1MTA0MCAg/
I have tried several but I have settled on Diigo.  It is just great!
I love pinboard. Collects links from my Google Reader favorites, Twitter favorites and Instapaper, archives a copy of web pages and have full text search.
i use the new.. diigo.com

Often I'll temporarily bookmark into whatever browser I'm using at the time. Otherwise, I 'bookmark' through Instapaper so that I am actually encouraged to read the items at a later date. (I seldom find myself needing to look back for something, or if I do, I'll just Google it again).
@michaelschade good point (...google it again...)
diigo here too, its consistently fast and no nonsense
@ct thanks for the heads up. but, funny b/c that was back in September and since have added more features. read this post "alive and kicking"  http://blog.xmarks.com/?p=2007
google bookmarks with yagbe extension for chrome
+1 for pinboard
Another hardcore pinboard user, well worth the paltry sum of money for the service

FWIW I just used the Google export of Delicious book marks to Google Bookmarks, took a few seconds.( wanted to just have the archive out of Delicious..). Removed the delicious add ins, Now exclusively use Diigo going forward.
I'm a GIA (Google It Again) kinda guy. I can't be bothered with bookmarks.

GIA never works well for me (the search results are constantly in flux; spam? algorithm changes?) but Google Bookmarks has never let me down. I admit I have a problem with putting so many eggs (mail, bookmarks, RSS reader, docs) in one basket but at least I know this company will be around for a while and not sold then neglected like, say, del.icio.us. That said, I'm starting to move more toward Evernote for this sort of stuff as typically I don't need to bookmark an entire site, just a specific article on it.
evernote! - saves whole pages as PDFs, or clip just the area of interest. plus tags are a much more intuitive way to organize this kind of data.

Pinboard.in is worth the small cost. Minimalistic UI and not riddled with annoying social sharing features. Pulls in data from multiple sources easily (e.g. twitter favourites) and you can pay an additional fee to get bookmark archiving, where the full permanent copy of the page is stored.
I just imported all my Delicious bookmarks into Google Bookmarks (because I can). I'm sticking with Springpad for day-to-day stuff though. It's fantastic.
I switched to google bookmarks, kinda tempted by pinboard but I want to at least see what the posting experience is like, I hacked up my own fork of the google one as its was 90% there
Right now its between Diigo and Pinboard for me. Still trying to figure out which is going to better suite my needs. The archiving/cache feature is key!

FWIW: I worked at Delicious. As far as I'm concerned, Pinboard is the spiritual successor. It's got a similar minimal UI and a lot of additional features I hoped we would've ended up building. (eg. bulk editing / tagging, read-later lists, content archival, auto-bookmarking from other services)
I use Diigo and Delicious
Pinboard and sometimes Springpad
+1 trunkly
Chrome, I use it on all my computers and it syncs to my google account
Delicious until it's gone, Pinboard next. Just can't get Google Bookmarks to work the way I think they should.

I've used google bookmarks for a long time, but now I'm trying out pinboard. I like it so far. Does anyone know if any of these sites allow markup in the description/notes fields when adding a bookmark? (kind of like a wiki markup just to add formatting to my notes)

The newest and pretty innovative bookmarking service I just featured on http://startupli.st is made by a 19 yr old from London. It's called http://HelvetiHome.com  The perfect home for you links. There is an activity feed that you can see and comment on your friends' links, organize your own into categories, and also use the intuitive quick search for Google, Twitter, Wikipedia, and Youtube. This is pretty much an awesome application. Anyone that tries it and wants to rate it, email me at nick @ betacandy.com, and I'll personally invite you to use http://BetaCandy.com. The early adopter marketplace, where you decide which startups are the best.
@0chris  I know many of the scripts mentioned on http://autonomo.us. But the scripts listed there were updated a long ago.
delicious
with some commandline tools; http://github.com/azer/bookmarks
for archiving of bookmarks. saving to your computer is the *only* solution. you never know when any of these companies are gonna die

Many good solutions listed here … I haven't tried the the Pinboard/Instapaper combination, so I'm going to look at that. I, too, have moved away from Delicious … jumped to Diigo as a stopgap measure … but like Diigo so much I may stay there.

I'm tempted to just move to Evernote since I'm using the app already … and the @myen Twitter trick is cool: "myEN lets you save tweets into your Evernote account. Setup instructions available at twitter.com/myEN." Works like Trunk.ly with the added benefit of Evernote organization.
google bookmark + instapaper
Still using delicious.. Lately I've been thinking of forking Reddit and convert it into an open source self hosted delicious clone.
hi
Google Notebook + del.icio.us

well I still find it highly useful and hope that they will not discontinue it. In fact, I would like to see it's presence in a form on android. Though that all depends on how high a priority the service is for them. I try not to think about where it ranks.
used del.icio.us since 2005 or so, I guess the only API that everyone else supports is theirs. As long as you regularly back it up it should be safe.
@weems I occasionally also use google notebook... one of those discontinued services that still is alive imagine that they killed waves and gizmo soon...
Google Bookmarks...I like how they appear in search results.
I used delicio.us for a while but made the switch to diigo a year or two ago.  They support in-page highlighting, notes and tags and will push your updates to delicio.us automatically if you like
Instapaper for articles, and pinboard for everything else.
Chrome bookmarks sync'd between desktop laptop and android phone with the help of ChromeMarksLite app

Generally most things I've ever wanted to save flow through Google Reader, but for bookmarking I use Diigo, and I've set it to automatically share every bookmark with Delicious to have at least one backup if either service ends...
Google Bookmarks for life.
Delicious for now...I'm still waiting to see what happens here. Instapaper has my attention though.
Instapaper + pinboard
ma.gnolia is my favorite....  oh wait, never mind  :(
I use Springpad for just about everything.
Instapaper and Pinboard for me
I'm using Delicious and those bookmarks are being imported into Trunk.ly. I also  use Instapaper, Evernote, and SpringPad for certain things.
Instapaper and previously Delicious.
Google bookmarks is all I need in the bookmarking game.
Pinboard, Instapaper, Laterstars. I've tried Google Bookmarks and like the UI (and lists) but there aren't many compatible applications yet so I use Pinboard.

I have been using X-Marks for some time and when it went to the paid version I kept right on using it. Because it is a cross browser application I use it on Chrome as well as on Firefox and IE. The fact that it is coupled with LastPass makes it even better for me.
I'm very happy with X-Marks as well.  And I immediately upgraded to Premium as soon as it came out to support the cause.
Google Bookmarks. Although I can't say I'm a heavy user of bookmarks anymore.
I use my Google Account via Chrome
Instapaper.
Instapaper here as well. I really like their iOS app, it ties in nicely.
Read it Later for me.  iOS app was $2 cheaper and it looks better IMO.
I use Chrome everywhere and so easy to sync my bookmarks.... delicious is like my backup
Instapaper on web and iOS
opo
@weems so del.icio.us is not dead?
licorize is pretty good
@geekwhisperer Instapaper has replaced Delicious for me.

Never thought of using Instapaper or Read It Later for bookmarks. I just finished cleaning and organizing my bookmarks between all my browsers. Sticking with Firefox and Firefox Sync until I can find something that will allow me to keep things organize across all browsers like Delicious used to.
Delicious at the moment, but I'm looking to switch.
@geekwhisperer It has the bookmarking and archiving features of Delicious plus a whole lot more. And it's cross-platform, so you can access your account on any kind of device.
@dustdaughter I've heard that from a few people. I'll have to check it out.
@dustdaughter I've also heard that Diigo is very good. I will have to compare the two.
http://radbox.me for bookmarking videos. Many wise people have called it the 'Instapaper for videos' !
Just using google bookmarks. It's so simple and has lots of features. No need for anything else. Instapaper and radbox looks nice :).
Still using delicious. Lets see what happens
@felipecerda I am too, but the service is completely stagnant.
